Award.AwardTitle: Houston Summer School on Dynamical Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the workshop ``Houston Summer School on Dynamical Systems'' (HSSDY) for graduate students in late May or early June 2018. The 2018 HSSDY workshop will be held at the University of Houston. The 2018 HSSDY workshop will bring together roughly 40 graduate students from institutions across the country, who will attend the 9-day event, along with 10-15 exceptional undergraduates, who will arrive several days earlier and will receive a series of background lectures giving them some of the tools they need in order to attend the main event. Additional information about the conference can be found on the website https://www.math.uh.edu/dynamics/school/school2018/

The HSSDY was funded by NSF from 2013 to 2017. The 2018 HSSDY workshop will continue the tradition of past workshops. The goal of the 2018 HSSDY workshop will introduce students both fundamental techniques and recent progress in dynamical systems. Moreover, the 2018 HSSDY workshop will introduce students the interrelationship between dynamical systems and other areas of mathematics and physics, including number theory, probability theory, statistical mechanics, and quantum information theory. Each lecturer in the 2018 HSSDY workshop will give students an appropriate bird's-eye view of the area in which he/she is working.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the project was to organize a summer school on dynamical systems at the University of Houston in May 2018, spanning roughly one week, for graduate students in dynamics. The lecture series was on probability and dynamical systems (including dynamics of quantum spin systems), with an emphasis on understanding statistical properties of chaotic dynamical systems.  The summer school was held during May 16-24, 2018. The lectures were given by the organizers (dynamics research group at UH), by 2 external guest lecturers, and one other member of the UH math department. There were 79 graduate and undergraduate participants, including those supported by other sources and local attendees. The attendance of the US graduate students was made possible and funded by this NSF grant.  The summer school gave participants an introduction to various topics that are of current research interest in dynamical systems and related fields, but that are difficult to learn oneself from the literature due to lack of expository material that is at an appropriate level for graduate students. Participants were also expected to read and discuss research papers. Through these projects and other guided reading the school also gave the participants a chance to engage with research literature and to work with peers at understanding current mathematical research in probability and dynamics.

In the exit survey the students gave very positive feedback to the school, and emphasized that they got very much out of it. They also appreciated that many of the lecturers were women.

As a broader impact of the summer school, the participants are now better positioned to pursue research in dynamical systems and related fields. Some of the graduate student participants were working primarily in math biology, physics or applied mathematics. These other disciplines will be enriched by the techniques and training provided to these young researchers. All participants are better able to use ideas from dynamical systems and probability in any STEM field they enter.  The full intellectual merit of the project will be realized by the participants research and other activities in STEM areas, which will have been enriched by the University of Houston Summer School in Dynamical Systems.

Videos of the summer school lectures are available for the general public, the links are posted at
https://www.math.uh.edu/dynamics/school/school2018/
https://www.math.uh.edu/dynamics/school/school2019/
